10.1016/j.jcat.2024.115548 The Author(s) Fig. 1 (a-c) The geometric structure of intrinsic 1T-HfTe2, 1T-HfTe2 with Te-vacancies, and the transition metal atoms embedded in Te-vacancies on the surface Graphical abstract Advancing efficient catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) or oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is imperative for commercializing emerging energy devices. Using density functional theory (DFT) calculations, we propose doping different transition metal (TM) atoms to regulate the electronic structures of the two-dimensional 1T-HfTe2 monolayer to achieve bifunctional catalysis for the ORR/OER. Due to the small electronegativity of the Hf atom, we found the doped TM atoms can generally form anion centers by accepting abundant charges from the Hf interlayer. At the same time, the highly conductive 1T-HfTe2 contributes to the charge transfer between the active center and the reaction intermediates, rendering the designed SACs the tunable activity for the reactions. By comparing the theoretical overpotentials of ORR and OER on 15 single-atom catalysts (SACs), Pt-doped system exhibits excellent catalytic activity for both ORR and OER, outperforming the traditional Pt(111) and RuO2(110) catalysts. Based on the charge transfer mechanism, we clarified that the doped TM atoms act as a ‘bridge’ to transfer the electrons from the substrate to the reaction intermediates, thereby effectively contributing to the improvement of catalytic activity. In summary, our study shows that, by doping appropriate TM atoms, the intrinsic inert HfTe2 can be activated toward efficient ORR/OER. This could provide some guidance for the design of new two-dimensional ORR/OER bifunctional catalyst materials. Keywords Single-atom catalysts Oxygen-related electrochemical reaction Bifunctional catalyst Density functional theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the rapid development of science and technology coupled with the continuous improvement of people’s living standards, the demand for energy is increasing in modern society [1,2]. Although the traditional fossil fuels are the reliable source with advantages of low price, and convenient storage, the large number of carbon-containing gases and soot emitted during their use which not only led to global warming and climate change but also caused great harm to human health. Moreover, the non-renewable nature of traditional fossil fuels makes them insufficient to support the continuous consumption of global human beings [3–5]. Therefore, eliminating the dependence on fossil fuels and developing new green sustainable energy are the inevitable choice for social stability and development [6,7]. As one of the most promising new energy technologies, electrochemical technology has significantly contributed to solving energy problems [8,9]. In recent years, various energy conversion devices including fuel cells, secondary batteries, and metal-air batteries have been proposed and made significant progress [10–14]. Notwithstanding these energy conversion devices have high theoretical conversion efficiency, low pollution, low noise, and high specific energy, they are normally restricted by the slow kinetics and the activity loss of the catalysts during redox reaction conditions, including oxygen reduction reactions (ORR) and oxygen evolution reactions (OER) [15–18]. Pt-based materials and noble metal oxide catalysts (such as IrO2 and RuO2) are the most effective and are widely used as the commercial ORR and OER electrocatalysts but suffer from high prices, scarce reserves, and poor stability [19–21]. Particularly, most of these catalysts only show a single function to catalyze a specific reaction, rendering them inadequate ability to deal with different electrochemical energy devices for large-scale market applications [22–24]. Therefore, reducing the number of precious metals, improving the utilization and durability of active elements, and developing bifunctional electrocatalysts for both ORR and OER have become leading research directions in recent years. Single-atom catalysts (SACs), refer to a class of catalysts in which the single active atoms are uniformly dispersed on a catalytic substrate, provide great potential to tackle issues in the conventional catalysts. In recent years, such catalysts have received extensive attention in chemistry and materials science [25,26]. Due to the atomically dispersed nature, single-atom catalyst has a 100 % metal unit point dispersion rate, which can maximize the use of metal atoms. At the same time, the flexible binding between the single metal atom and the substrate material, as well as the effective coordination of the controllability of the local environment can achieve efficient and controllable reaction processes in various catalytic applications [27,28]. The key point of designing SACs is to anchor single atoms stably on the substrate. Appropriate support can not only improve the utilization of single metal atoms but also realize the strong interaction between single metal atoms and support, thereby regulating and improving catalytic performance [29–31]. Two-dimensional transition metal chalcogenides (TMDs) are of great promise to be catalytic supports due to their unique electronic, optical, mechanical, and chemical properties, high specific surface area and layered structure conducive to rapid ion migration, and have been successfully applied in the field of electrocatalysis [32–37]. For example, Upadhyay et al. predicted Pt atom doped MoSe2 monolayer to be the efficient catalyst for ORR and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [38]. Sun et al. demonstrated that Sc-, V-, Fe-, Co– and Cu- doped PtS2 exhibit excellent CO2 Reduction Reaction (CO2RR) catalytic activity, and their limiting potentials are relatively low even better than the most active single metal of Cu(211) [39]. It is worth noting that most of previous research devoted to design of TMDs-based materials for a single reaction, and the studied objects were limited to a small group of TMDs, such as TiSe2, MoSe2, and MoS2, etc. Other TMDs with metallic nature for both ORR and OER are rarely explored. We note that although Te is a rare element, telluride-based catalysts are widely studied, because its lower electronegativity and stronger metallicity of Te element than other chalcogenide elements (such as Se, S) which lead to higher covalentity and stronger conductivity of metal-tellurium bonds in transition metal tellurides (TMTs) [40]. Such covalent characteristic then results in a favorable electronic band structure, contributing to electrocatalytic performance improvement [41]. Nevertheless, the large portion of rare element of Te in the conventional catalysts could limit their practical applications even if they exhibit excellent catalytic activity. To develop applicable Te-based catalysts, it is necessary to minimize the utilization of Te. In this regard, two-dimensional (2D) HfTe2 possesses the intrinsic advantage of high specific surface area than the corresponding bulk phase which can greatly maximum the active area of catalysts while reducing the loading of catalysts. Inspired by this, our research employed the first-principles calculation method to discover a large group of SACs based on the conductive 1T-HfTe2. First, binding energy, analysis proved superior stability of metal atom on the Te defect of 1T-HfTe2. Then, we identified a theoretical descriptor of d-band center and employed it to screen catalysts with high ORR and OER catalytic activity. We finally discovered that Pd@HfTe2 and Pt@HfTe2 exhibit commendable performance in monofunctional catalysis for ORR, Ir@HfTe2 and Pt@HfTe2 for OER, and Pt@HfTe2 is a catalyst with good ORR/OER bifunctional catalytic activity. To exemplify the catalytic origin of these catalysts, we calculated the electronic properties of these structures and analyzed the interaction between the active center and the reaction intermediate during the reaction process. We found that the active center, as a medium for electron transport between the carrier and the reaction intermediate, can rationally adjust the appropriate adsorption strength between the catalyst and the reaction intermediate to minimum the energy barrier for each reaction step, thereby reducing the overpotential of the entire reaction. This study aims to provide a compelling idea for designing a new HfTe2-based SACs, enrich its application in electrocatalysis, and give some guidance for experiments and practical applications. 2 Computational details 2.1 Research method The structural optimization and electronic properties calculations were based on the density functional theory (DFT) which were carried out using the Vienna ab initio simulation program (VASP) [42,43]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange–correlation functional based on the Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) was used to realize the exchange–correlation [44,45]. To include the dynamic correlation-induced van der Waals interaction upon adsorption, we used the empirical correction method of DFT-D3 to deal with the dispersion interaction [46]. 3 × 3 × 1 supercell of 1T-HfTe2, which contains 9 Hf atoms and 18 Te atoms was used for the catalytic evaluation. In order to eliminate the interlayer interaction and ensure the space required for the catalytic reaction, a vacuum layer of 20 Å was incorporated along the Z-axis direction of the lattice. The plane wave truncation energy is set to 450 eV, and the projector augmented wave (PAW) method describes the potential field generated by the inner electrons and the nucleus to the outer electrons [47]. In the structure relaxation process, the energy convergence threshold for the atoms is set to 1.0 × 10-5 eV/atom, and the force convergence threshold is set to 0.01 eV/Å. The Brillouin zone is sampled by the Monkhorst-Pack method. The geometric optimization of the structure is selected with the 5 × 5 × 1 K-point, and the calculation of the electronic structure is using the 11 × 11 × 1 K-point. The minimum energy paths and the energy barriers for oxygen dissociation and hydrogenation steps are obtained by the climb image nudged elastic band (NEB) method [48,49]. 2.2 Calculation contents The binding energy of a single transition metal atoms to the Te-vacancy on the 1T-HfTe2 substrate and the cohesive energy of the transition metal atoms are calculated by the equations (1)-(2): (1) E b = E TM @ H f T e 2 - E Sub - E TM - S i n g l e (2) E coh = E TM - B u l k / N - E TM - S i n g l e Among them, E TM @ H f T e 2 is the total energy of TM@HfTe2 doped with transition metal atoms in 1T-HfTe2 with Te-vacancy, E Sub is the total energy of 1T-HfTe2 with Te-vacancy defects, while E TM - B u l k , E TM - S i n g l e and N are the total energy of the bulk phase structure of bulk transition metal atoms, the energy of a single transition metal atom in vacuum and the number of atoms in the bulk phase structure of bulk transition metal atoms, respectively. To systematically study the thermodynamic and electrochemical stability of all monoatomic catalysts constructed, the formation energy ( E f ) and dissolution potential ( U diss , versus SHE) are used for evaluation, and the definitions are shown in equations (3)-(4), respectively [50]. (3) E f = E TM @ HfTe 2 - E Sub - E TM - B u l k (4) U diss = U diss ° M e t a l , B u l k - E f / n e Among them, U diss ° ( M e t a l , B u l k ) and n are the standard dissolution potential of bulk metal and the number of electrons involved in the dissolution, respectively. The adsorption energies ( E ads ) of the reaction intermediates (O atom, O2, OH, OOH, and H2O molecules) on the designed catalyst is defined as equation (5): (5) E ads = E ad / S - E ad - E S where, E ad / S , E ad , and E S represent the total energy of the intermediate product adsorbed on the catalyst surface, the energy of the free adsorbates, and the energy of the catalyst substrate material, respectively. In addition, we also calculated the free energy change of the reaction according to the method proposed by Nørskov et al [51]. More information regarding the calculations can be found in the supplementary materials. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure models and their stability Typically, TMDs are formed by the tetravalent transition metal and the bivalent chalcogens. The different arrangements of metal and chalcogen atoms will make diverse phases of TMDs [52], including 1T, 1T’, 2H, 3R, and Td phases [53]. Among them, 2H phase is usually to be the most stable phase, but the resulting TMDs normally show semiconductor properties. To achieve high conductivity for electrochemical reactions, it is necessary to change from the 2H phase to the metastable 1T phase, which undoubtedly increases the difficulty of catalyst preparation and arises the stability issue. Differently, HfTe2 system shows the most stable phase of 1T in the phase diagram space, and the intrinsic zero band gap which makes it to present metal properties to enhance the charge transfer and facilitate electrocatalytic reaction. Therefore, 1T-HfTe2 was selected as the catalytic support to design SACs (Fig. 1 a). We note that experimental studies have found that compared with Hf vacancies, Te-vacancies have lower formation energy and are the common point defects to interact with impurity atoms [54,55], we constructed a Te-vacancy defect on the surface of 1T-HfTe2 as a doping substrate, as shown in Fig. 1b. Then, based on this structure, TM atoms are doped to design a series of SACs, namely TM@HfTe2 (Fig. 1c). 15 TM atoms involved in 3d, 4d, and 5d periods were considered to dope at Te-vacancies on the surface of 1T-HfTe2 (Fig. 1d). For SACs, the strong binding between the metal dopant and defect site is a prerequisite for preventing the aggregation of TM atoms on the catalytic support, and maintaining its catalytic activity for an extended duration. In order to study the possibility of embedding TM atoms in Te-vacancies and verify the stability of these SACs, we used the equation (1) to calculate the binding energy. From Table S1, it is found that Te-vacancies can effectively capture the doped TM atoms and form three metal-Hf bonds with the atoms. The calculated binding energies falls within the range of −1.46 to −8.53 eV, indicating that these configurations have good thermodynamic stability. In particular the more negative values than that of cohesive energies suggest that the TM atoms are capable of being immobilized on the HfTe2 surface and forming the single atom sites. In addition, we find that the formation energies of these SACs are also negative (see Fig. 2 a). According to the definition, a negative E f (<0) indicates that it is thermodynamically beneficial to forming the monatomic moieties, and can inhibit the diffusion and aggregation of metal atoms. In these SACs, except for Fe, Zn, and Cd doped systems, the dissolution potential of the other systems are positive relative to the equilibrium potential (>0 V vs. SHE), indicating that the TM atoms embedded in these configurations are stable enough to bind to the carrier, and the dissolution of the TM atoms can be avoided under electrochemical conditions, thus ensuring the long-term performance of the catalyst. The average bond length of the formed TM-Hf bonds enlarges with the increase of the atomic number in the same period (see Fig. 2b and 2c), and some of TMs show weak protuberance relative to the cavity plane. The deviation height of the TM atoms is highly related to the atomic radius (R). In order to further understand the stability of the related structures, we used the Bader charge method to analyze the charge transfer between the TM and HfTe2 (Fig. 2d). Surprisingly, due to the small electronegativity of the bonded Hf atoms, we observed a reverse charge transfer pathway distinguish from the conventional SAC systems such as M−N−C [56], that is, the charges are transferred from the 1T-HfTe2 to the larger electronegative TM atoms, making TM atoms are negatively charged. For the TM atoms of the same period, the charge transfer increases first and then decrease gradually with the increase of atomic number. Such abnormal charge states might offer the catalysts different catalytic performance for the ORR and OER. 3.2 Catalytic activity of TM@HfTe2 for ORR and OER The efficiency of fuel cells is strongly associated with the catalytic performance of the catalysts [57]. Therefore, we next studied the catalytic activity of OER and ORR on the designed SACs. Note that the OER reaction is the reverse reaction of the ORR reaction, we took the ORR reaction as an example to conduct a preliminary study. As shown in Fig. S1, the ORR involves two competitive reaction pathways: (1) 2e- reaction path, which makes O2 eventually convert to H2O2; (2) 4e- reaction pathway, which leads to the final conversion of O2 to H2O. The equilibrium potentials of these two paths are 0.70 and 1.23 eV versus standard reversible hydrogen electrode (SHE), respectively. To maximum efficiency, the 4e- pathway is more ideal than the 2e- path [58]. Firstly, in order to determine the catalytic selectivity of SACs in the redox process, we investigated the adsorption behavior of H2O2 molecules on these catalyst surfaces. As shown in Fig. S2, the interaction between the H2O2 and catalysts readily makes the H2O2 decomposition into two OH groups. This result indicated that the H2O2 molecule is hard to form on the 15 SACs, and the resulting ORR and OER go through the 4e- pathway [59]. Following which we studied the oxygen adsorption on the SACs with the consideration of two adsorption modes, including side-on adsorption, and end-on adsorption. O2 molecule inclines to be adsorbed on the Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Cd, Os, and Hg@HfTe2 via in the end-on mode and form two TM-O bonds. Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Ir, Pt, and Au@HfTe2 surfaces prefer to adsorb O2 by side-on configuration. Whereas Fe@HfTe2 shows the strong binding with oxygen, which enables to directly break the O-O bond (Fig. S3). Compared with the O-O bond length (dO-O = 1.21 Å) of the free O2 molecule, all the adsorbed O2 molecules except the dissociated O2 on the Fe@HfTe2 display elongated O-O the bond is elongated due to the strong coupling between the TM-d and O2-2p orbitals, indicating they are activated. Therefore, we will use these 14 SACs for the subsequent evaluations. According to previous studies, the d-band center theory can be used as a very simple and reliable descriptor to describe the adsorption energy of intermediate products [60]. Therefore, before studying the reaction mechanism, we first used the d-band center theory to preliminary predict the catalytic activity of these SACs. Since Pt(111) and RuO2 are the most commonly used commercial catalysts for ORR and OER reactions, we introduced Pt(111) and RuO2 catalysts as references to study the d-band centers of metal sites on the catalyst surface [61,62]. The closer the center of the d-band is to the Pt(111) or RuO2 catalyst, the metal active site may have moderate adsorption energy for the reaction intermediate and better catalytic activity for ORR or OER reaction [63,64]. From Fig. 3 a, we found that the d-band center values of Pd and Pt single atom doped configurations are very close to the d-band center values of Pt(111) and RuO2 (shown in the red and green dotted line, respectively), which are 2.57 eV and 2.78 eV, respectively, suggesting that these SACs may have good catalytic activity for ORR or OER. In order to verify this conjecture, we investigated the full reaction diagram of all considered SACs, and constructed the activity volcano plot between the overpotential and adsorption energy of reaction species (see Fig. 3b). Exactly, Pd@HfTe2 and Pt@HfTe2 that initially screened from the d-band center analysis have moderate binding for the O-containing intermediates (O, OH, OOH) than other SACs, and are located near the peak of the volcano plot, indicating that these catalysts have suitable electronic structures and better catalytic activity than other configurations. As an example, we also checked the possible reaction pathway of dissociation mechanism on the Pt@HfTe2 surface as illustrated in Fig. S1. The NEB calculation results showed that the O2 dissociation needs to overcome a high energy barrier of about 0.82 eV, indicating that O2 is difficult to dissociate on the surface of Pt@HfTe2 monolayer at room temperature, thus hindering the reaction. Therefore, the adsorbed O2 molecule is expected to interact with protons, resulting in the formation of OOH* intermediates on the surface. The reaction energy barrier is only 0.21 eV, indicating that the OOH* intermediates are easily generated, so on the surface of these SACs, OOH* is the common product of the first step of ORR and the penultimate step of OER [65]. Therefore, we proposed that the 4e- hydrogenation mechanism could lead in the ORR and OER (see Fig. 3c). In addition, from the perspective of implicit and explicit solvation effects, we considered the solvation effect on the ORR/OER catalytic activity of Pt@HfTe2 catalyst, and the solvation model is shown in Fig. S4. On this basis, we first calculated the correction energy of the solution (ΔSol) and the Gibbs free energy of all the reaction intermediates on the Pt@HfTe2 surface in an aqueous environment by VASPsol (the calculation results are counted in Table S2). The analysis of the above research results shows that the reaction intermediates involved in ORR and OER are stabilized to varying degrees through the interaction of hydrogen bonds with environmental water molecules, which in turn has a certain impact on the overall ORR and OER reaction process. As shown in Fig. S5, the potential-limiting step of the ORR reaction of Pt@HfTe2 in an aqueous solution environment becomes the formation process of O2 → OOH*, while the potential-limiting step of the OER reaction does not change. At the same time, the overpotential of the ORR reaction changed from 0.44 V to 0.47 V, while the overpotential of OER changed from 0.40 V to 0.46 V, indicating that the Pt@HfTe2 system exhibited good ORR/OER catalytic activity regardless of whether it was in an aqueous solution environment. Therefore, it can be preliminarily considered that the aqueous solution environment has no significant effect on the overall catalytic activity of the Pt@HfTe2 catalyst. Subsequently, to verify this conjecture, we further analyze it from the perspective of the explicit solvation effect. Through molecular dynamics simulation, the convergent temperature equilibrium and energy fluctuation curves at T = 500 K are given (see Fig. S6). It can be seen from the figure that after the simulation of 20 ps at this temperature, the fluctuation range of all curves is relatively small, indicating that the configuration of the oxygen-containing intermediate adsorbed on the metal active site on the Pt@HfTe2 surface still has good thermal stability. To compare the charge transfer from the catalyst to the reaction intermediate in the environment with or without aqueous solution and the corresponding bond cooperation, the configuration of OH* intermediate adsorption was discussed as an example. As shown in the Bader charge in Fig. S7a, c, the difference in the number of charges transferred from the metal active site Pt to the OH* intermediate in the aqueous solution environment is 0.2 e- compared with that in the non-aqueous solution environment, indicating that the Pt@HfTe2 system is very close to the activation degree of the reaction intermediate in the two environments. In addition, we also examined the PDOS of the Pt@HfTe2 system after the adsorption of the OH* intermediate (see Fig. S7b, d). It was found that under both environmental conditions, the α- and β- spin d orbitals of Pt have similar orbital overlaps with the p orbital of the bonded O, so they all exhibit strong interactions, which is conducive to sufficient charge transfer between the metal sites and the reaction intermediates, which is also the reason why the Pt@HfTe2 catalyst can also have excellent catalytic activity in an aqueous solution environment. In the crystal orbital Hamiltonian layout number (COHP) and integral COHP (ICOHP) analysis, the similar bonding strength of Pt-O and O–H also proves our conjecture. In summary, although the aqueous solution does have a certain effect on the adsorption energy of the reaction intermediates on the catalyst surface, its effect on the general trend of catalytic activity could be small [66]. Therefore, we focused on the following investigations in terms of the constant-charge calculations. In theory, we should also include the adsorption of O2 molecules when calculating the Gibbs free energy of the intermediate adsorbed on the catalyst surface. However, previous studies have reported that this process is a chemical step, and the steady-state adsorption of this neutral reactant will not lead to the potential dependence of Faraday current. If the coupling between the adsorbed O2 molecule and the metal active site is strong enough, the charge transfer is unlikely to be the rate limit of the process [67]. To further explore whether the adsorption-free energy of the introduced O2 molecule will affect the catalytic activity of our designed SACs for ORR reaction, we calculated the theoretical overpotentials of all SACs with or without ΔGO2* in Table S3 and Table S4, respectively, and fitted the linear proportional relationship between η ORR and η O 2 ORR (see Fig. S8). Through comparative analysis, it was found that there was a good linear correlation between the two, R2 = 0.98, indicating that for the TM@HfTe2 system, the introduction of O2 molecular adsorption-free energy did not change its overall catalytic activity. In detail, the reaction diagrams of ORR on the TM@HfTe2 at different electrode potentials were shown in Fig. 4 , and Figs. S9-10. Among all constructed SACs, Fe@HfTe2 and Co@HfTe2 are uphill in energy at the condition of zero potential, implying large overpotential over 1.23 eV. Therefore, we excluded these two systems for the subsequent evaluations. The ORR on the other SACs is more energy-favorable with downhill energy in each elementary step at zero potential. For Ni, Cu, Zn, Rh, Cd, Os, Ir, and Pt@HfTe2, the potential-limiting step is the formation of OH* → H2O. The potential-limiting step of Ru@HfTe2 is the formation process of O* → OH*, while the potential-limiting step of Pd, Ag, Au, and Hg@HfTe2 is the formation of OOH*. The theoretical overpotential (ɳ ORR) of TM@HfTe2 can be calculated via the following equation: η O R R = 1.23 - M I N [ 4.92 - Δ G O O H , Δ G O O H - Δ G O , Δ G O - Δ G O H , Δ G O H ] e V where MIN represents the minimum free energy difference in the four-electron transfer steps. 4.92 is the ΔG value of a gaseous O2 molecule referred to the H2 and H2O, and 1.23 eV is the equilibrium potential of ORR in an acidic medium (pH = 0). It is found that among many SACs, TM@HfTe2 of Rh, Pd, Ag, Cd, Pt, and Hg all show excellent ORR catalytic activity. Among them, the overpotentials of Pd and Pt@HfTe2 are the lowest, and the ORR is 0.44 V, which is even better than the traditional commercial ORR catalyst Pt(111) [68]. For the OER, the free energy change and overpotential of the OER on the TM@HfTe2 were also assessed. Similar to the ORR, the corresponding calculation formula for the OER overpotential is as follows: η O E R = M A X [ 4.92 - Δ G O O H , Δ G O O H - Δ G O , Δ G O - Δ G O H , Δ G O H ] - 1.23 e V where MAX is the maximum value among four energy difference of neighboring elementary steps. Fig. 5 and Fig. S11 presented the Gibbs free energy diagrams of OER. Except for Fe@HfTe2 and Co@HfTe2, all the other 13 TM@HfTe2 exhibited large energy requirement at the zero potential. The potential-limiting steps of OER on the Ni, Cu, Zn, Rh, Pd, Ag, Cd, Ir, Pt, Au, and Hg is the second step (OH* → O*), while the reaction is restricted in the third step (O* → OOH*) on the Ru and Os@HfTe2. TM@HfTe2 composed of Ni, Rh, Ir, Pt, and Au exhibit excellent OER catalytic activity. Their corresponding overpotentials are 0.50 V, 0.63 V, 0.47 V, 0.40 V, and 0.71 V, respectively, which are equivalent to or even smaller than the most advanced RuO2 catalyst, indicating that these SACs are potential candidate materials for the OER [69]. Overall, combined with the analyses of ORR and OER, we summarized the corresponding overpotential of the catalyst (Fig. 6 a and Fig. S12), the catalytic preference of different material can be evaluated. We found Rh, Pd, Ag, Cd, and Hg SACs possess good performance for the ORR, and four systems with TMs of Co, Ni, Rh, and Ir have the good activity for the OER. Pt exhibited bifunctional characteristic for both ORR and OER (Fig. 6b). 3.3 Essential role in determining the activity of ORR and OER Previous unveiled that the ORR/OER activity of the catalyst mainly depends on the binding strength between the catalysts and oxygen-containing intermediates [70,71]. Therefore, to further understand the catalytic trend of TM@HfTe2, we inspected the relationship between adsorption free energies of OOH* and OH* on these catalysts (i.e., ΔGOOH* and ΔGOH*). As shown in Fig. 7 a, we found a directly linear correlation of ΔGOOH* = 0.88ΔGOH* + 3.36, with high determination coefficient R2 of 0.99. This enables us to deduce the catalytic relationship between ORR and OER by studying the binding strength of one of the reaction intermediates on the catalyst [72]. Then, we fitted the volcanic curve of activity using the ΔGOH* and overpotential ɳ ORR as descriptor for the ORR (as shown in Fig. 7b) and ΔGOOH* − ΔGO* and ɳ OER for the OER (Fig. 7c). The catalytic activity of traditional high-performance catalysts Pt(111) and RuO2(110) were used as the reference in the volcano plots. It can be seen from Fig. 7b that the optimal catalytic activity is achieved at ΔGOH* value of 0.84 eV. When the free energy value is less than 0.84 eV, the potential-limiting step occurs in the step of OH* → H2O or OH* → O* and the resulting catalysts located in the left branch of the volcano plot. When the free energy value is larger than 0.84 eV, the potential-limiting step occurs in the O2 → OOH* step at the right branch of the volcano plot. For the OER (Fig. 7c), the corresponding optimal catalytic activity is realized at the ΔGOOH* − ΔGO* value of 1.65 eV. When the free energy value is less than 1.65 eV, the potential-limiting step occurs in the O* → OOH* step and the catalysts located in the left branch of the volcano plot. When the free energy is more positive than 1.65 eV, the potential-limiting step occurs at the OH* → O* step, and SACs are distributed at the right branch of the volcano. Because Pt@HfTe2 is located at the top of the two volcano plots, the suitable interaction strength between it and the reaction intermediate offers it the bifunctional activity for both ORR and OER. To gain a deeper insight into the catalytic origin of the selected SACs, we calculated a range of electronic properties of the catalysts. To begin with, the density of states (DOS) of all designed SACs were calculated as shown in Fig. 8 a-c. Cu, Zn, Ag, Cd, Au, and Hg@HfTe2 showed high density of states near the Fermi level, and Hf-5d electrons mainly contribute to the electronic density of states in terms of high conductive nature of HfTe2. This endows effective charge transfer process between the single atom sites and the substrate, as well as the SACs and the reaction intermediates during the reaction. However, excessive electrons compared to the requisite amount for the reaction intermediate resulted in a strong interaction between the catalyst and the reaction intermediate, making the product difficult to desorb from these catalyst surface. In contrast, the density of states of Fe, Co, Ni, Pd, Ru, Rh, Os, and Ir@HfTe2 catalysts at the Fermi level are reduced, indicating that these catalysts may not be able to donate adequate electrons to facilitate the adsorption and conversion of reaction species. Differently, Pt@HfTe2 has moderate density of states at the Fermi level, so the interaction with the reaction intermediate tends to be mild. In addition, the charge transfer mechanism further revealed the nature of the bifunctional catalytic activity of Pt@HfTe2. As shown in Fig. 8d, the differential charge diagram indicates that the path of charge transfer is that electrons first transfer from the Hf atomic layer to the Pt single atom and then to the reaction intermediates. Therefore, the Pt single atom can be considered as a medium for the charge transfer from the Hf atom layer to the reaction intermediates. The high conductivity and plenty of Hf-5d electrons hold a large contribution to its catalytic performance. 4 Conclusions In summary, we carried out comprehensive theoretical calculations and systematically studied the ORR and OER catalytic activity of a series of SACs composed of TM atoms doped on the surface of 1T-HfTe2 with Te-vacancy. We observed an unusual charge transfer process between the HfTe2 and TM atoms, rending the doped single atoms as the anion center toward oxygen electrocatalysis. Among 15 designed SACs, Pt@HfTe2 is regarded as a highly effective bifunctional catalyst for ORR/OER reaction due to its lower overpotential (ɳ ORR = 0.44 V and ɳ OER = 0.40 V). We elucidated that the Pt single atom can be regarded as a medium for the charge transfer from the Hf atom layer to the reaction intermediates, and the highly conductive nature of HfTe2 and plenty of Hf-5d electrons hold a large contribution to its catalytic performance. This work not only provides an effective method for designing new bifunctional SACs but also further expands the potential application of HfTe2-based materials in the field of electrocatalysis. coredata.dc:description: Advancing efficient catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) or oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is imperative for commercializing emerging energy devices. Using density functional theory (DFT) calculations, we propose doping different transition metal (TM) atoms to regulate the electronic structures of the two-dimensional 1T-HfTe2 monolayer to achieve bifunctional catalysis for the ORR/OER. Due to the small electronegativity of the Hf atom, we found the doped TM atoms can generally form anion centers by accepting abundant charges from the Hf interlayer. At the same time, the highly conductive 1T-HfTe2 contributes to the charge transfer between the active center and the reaction intermediates, rendering the designed SACs the tunable activity for the reactions. By comparing the theoretical overpotentials of ORR and OER on 15 single-atom catalysts (SACs), Pt-doped system exhibits excellent catalytic activity for both ORR and OER, outperforming the traditional Pt(111) and RuO2(110) catalysts. Based on the charge transfer mechanism, we clarified that the doped TM atoms act as a ‘bridge’ to transfer the electrons from the substrate to the reaction intermediates, thereby effectively contributing to the improvement of catalytic activity. In summary, our study shows that, by doping appropriate TM atoms, the intrinsic inert HfTe2 can be activated toward efficient ORR/OER. This could provide some guidance for the design of new two-dimensional ORR/OER bifunctional catalyst materials.
